intro: Asperula phrygia, commonly known as the Phrygian snowbell, is a deciduous shrub native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It is characterized by its slender, arching stems and clusters of small, bell-shaped white flowers that bloom in early spring. The leaves are typically alternate, simple, and ovate with a slightly serrated margin. This plant thrives in well-drained, acidic soils and prefers partial to full shade. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and can be found in botanical gardens and native plant collections.
